{{Infobox civilian attack | title = April 2000 Gambian student massacre | partof = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | location = [[Banjul]], [[The Gambia]] | target = | coordinates = | date = 10 April 2000 | time = | timezone = | type = | fatalities = 15 | injuries = 80+, 28 critical | victims = 14 students, one Red Cross volunteer, one child | perpetrators= Gambian police officers and soldiers | assailants = <!-- or | assailant = --> | susperps = <!-- or | susperp = --> | weapons = | numparts = <!-- or | numpart = --> | dfens = <!-- or | dfen = --> | motive = | inquiry = Lartey Commission | coroner = | accused = | convicted = | verdict = | convictions = | charges = | litigation = | website ={{URL|www.april1011gambia.org/}} | module = }}
The '''April 2000 Gambian student massacre''' was the killing of 14 people (and one accidental death) by Gambian police officers and soldiers on the 10 April 2000 at a student protest in [[Banjul]], [[the Gambia]]. The protest had been called following two separate incidents - the beating to death of secondary school student Ebrima Barry by firefighters, and the rape of a 13-year-old girl by a uniformed police officer - and the lack of investigation of both of those incidents. Despite firing live ammunition into the protesters after government buildings had been damaged, no charges have been brought against those involved, and the [[Yahya Jammeh]] government suppressed commemoration of the event. [[Adama Barrow]]'s government has since promised to investigate the shooting.
== Background == [[File:Independence Stadium (Gambia) 0002.jpg|left|thumb|240x240px|The entrance to [[Independence Stadium (Bakau)|Independence Stadium]], where the alleged rape took place.]] On 8 March 2000, 19-year-old secondary school student Ebrima Barry was murdered by firefighters in [[Brikama]], [[West Coast Division (Gambia)|West Coast Division]]. Barry's teacher, a Mr Paul, had called firefighters to the school after Barry had insulted him, in order to remove Barry from the classroom, as he was afraid of a physical altercation. However, the firefighters not only removed him from the school but took him to their station where they shaved his head, beat him, forced him to carry heavy bags of cement, stripped him naked, poured cement on him and finally put cement in his mouth and forced him to swallow it. He was able to get home that night but died the next day from his injuries. Later in the week, students from Barry's secondary school converged on the local fire station in protest but were dispersed by police officers.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://nvdatabase.swarthmore.edu/content/gambian-students-protest-killing-student-and-rape-13-year-old-2000|title=Gambian students protest killing of student and rape of 13-year-old, 2000|last=|first=|date=|website=Global Nonviolent Action Database|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=17 June 2017}}</ref>
The government failed to investigate the matter, leading to the Gambia Student Union (GAMSU) leadership calling for an inquiry. The government, besides expressing surprise that firefighters had been asked to discipline a student, made no further move to investigate the matter. An autopsy report was released which stated that Barry had died of natural causes. The report was widely perceived to be a cover-up. A spontaneous protest ensued at The Gambia College, where GAMSU was active, as well as at other schools. The courts eventually charged seven firefighters with participating in Barry's death, but all seven were acquitted on 2 March 2001.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://thepoint.gm/africa/gambia/article/april-1011-2000-student-massacre-victims-families-demand-justice|title=April 10/11 2000, student massacre victims: families demand Justice|last=|first=|date=11 April 2017|work=The Point|access-date=17 June 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
Concurrently with the developments surrounding Barry's murder, a 13-year-old girl, known in the press as Binta, was allegedly raped by a uniformed paramilitary police officer (part of the Police Intervention Unit) at the [[Independence Stadium (Bakau)|Independence Stadium]] during an inter-schools sports competition. A medical examination confirmed that the girl had been raped, and GAMSU again pressed the government for answers, calling for the girl to be allowed to identify the rapist. Following a long delay in any government action, GAMSU requested a police permit to hold a public protest. The request was denied, but, referring to their constitutional right to protest, GAMSU called its members to take part in a peaceful march towards the capital city of [[Banjul]].<ref name=":1" />
== Incident == GAMSU decided to hold their protest march on 10 April 2000, and 'thousands' reportedly gathered outside the Gambia Technical Training Institute intending to march towards the [[Banjul]] city centre. However, they were stopped by police officers, who ordered them to disperse. Refusing to do so, the police opened fire on the protest with tear gas and rubber bullets. The students then scattered but regrouped, creating barricades out of burning tires and throwing stones at the police. As non-students then joined the fray, government buildings were attacked and a police station was set on fire.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/gambian-police-open-fire-on-student-demonstration-282095.html|title=Gambian police open fire on student demonstration|last=|first=|date=9 April 2000|work=The Independent|access-date=17 June 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
The police then reacted by opening fire on the protesters with live ammunition. They killed 16 people, 14 of whom were students, as well as a journalist and [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|Red Cross]] volunteer, Omar Barrow, and a three-year-old child. Hundreds were reported to have been injured. Immediately following the shooting, people were barred by the police from entering the local hospital to identify the dead.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> A statement released by the President's office following the shooting stated that 28 people had been admitted to [[Royal Victoria Teaching Hospital]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/709845.stm|title=Protests at Gambia killings|last=|first=|date=11 April 2000|work=BBC News|access-date=17 June 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> A student nurse drafted in to help during the massacre later described how there was "immediate chaos in the hospital" and how during emergency operations on gunshot wounds, radio stations were saying that only rubber bullets had been used.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://gainako.com/an-eye-witness-account-to-gambias-student-massacre-in-2000/|title=An eye witness Account to Gambia’s Student Massacre in 2000|last=|first=|date=10 April 2014|work=Gainako|access-date=17 June 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
=== Victims === The full list of those killed is as follows.<ref name=":1" /> Further details are those from a coroner's inquest published by ''[[Foroyaa]]'' in 2014.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gambia.dk/forums/topic.asp?TOPIC_ID=13790|title=APRIL 10 CRISIS ("The key finding was made by the Coroner.")|last=Njie|first=Ousman|date=13 April 2014|work=Foroyaa|access-date=17 June 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|via=gambia.dk}}</ref> * Reginald Carroll, student of La Fourmi Institute, died of gunshot wounds * Karamo Barrow, former student of the Institute for Continuing Education, died of gunshot wounds * Lamin Bojang, student of Nusrat Senior Secondary School, died of gunshot wounds * Ousman Sabally, student of Brikamaba Upper Basic School, died of gunshot wounds * Sainey Nyabally, not mentioned in report * Ousman Sembene, not mentioned in report * Bakary Njie, not mentioned in report * Claesco Pierra, resident of New Jeshwang, died of gunshot wounds * Momodou Lamin Njie, student of Gambia Technical Training Institute, died of gunshot wounds * Wuyea Foday Mansareh, student of Tallinding Islamic Institute, died of gunshot wounds * Bamba Jobarteh, not mentioned in report * Momodou Lamin Chune, student of Latrikunda Middle School, died of gunshot wounds * Abdoulie Sanyang, from Old Jeshwang, died from accidental trampling * Babucarr Badjie, 10-year-old student, died of gunshot wounds * Omar Barrow, journalist and [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|Red Cross]] volunteer, died of gunshot wounds
== Aftermath ==
=== Government response === Following the shooting, the government denied allegations that [[President of the Gambia|President]] [[Yahya Jammeh]] had given the order to shoot the students. During the crisis, he had been away in [[Cuba]] for a summit of the [[Group of 77]].<ref name=":2" /> Instead, they issued a statement that blamed student leaders and closed all schools for several days. The statement said: "There is no doubt that the crisis was incited by the Gambia Students Union and aggravated by some bad elements and bandits who took advantage of the situation, disguising themselves as students and encouraging the crowd of so-called demonstrators to the damage."<ref name=":2" />
Later, the Vice-President, [[Isatou Njie-Saidy]], claimed that the students "killed themselves", having broken into police armouries and shot each other with stolen weapons.<ref name=":0" /> Also, following the incident, families of the victims were in no way compensated by the government and commemoration events were banned for the rest of Jammeh's presidency, until 2017.<ref name=":1" /> A subsequent government commission of inquiry, under [[Chief Justice of the Gambia|Chief Justice]] Felix Lartey, concluded that Police Intervention Unit (PIU) officers were "largely responsible" for carrying out the shooting. On 26 January 2001, the government announced that it disagreed with the commission's recommendations and that nobody would be prosecuted. <ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/af/8377.htm|title=Gambia - Country Reports on Human Rights Practices|last=|first=|date=4 March 2002|website=State Department|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=17 June 2017}}</ref>
On 18 April, the National Assembly approved an Indemnity Bill that backdated to January 2000 and amended the Indemnity Act of 1982, allowing Jammeh to [[Indemnity|indemnify]] anyone "for the purpose of promoting reconciliation in an appropriate case." Jammeh signed the bill in May. In essence, it prevented the families of those killed from seeking redress in the courts.<ref name=":3" /> [[Hawa Sisay-Sabally]] has since described the act as "tantamount to a coup against the [[Constitution of the Gambia|1997 constitution]]" and it has been widely criticised.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://smbcgo.com/2017/04/27/gambia-will-indemnity-act-repealed/|title=Gambia: Will the Indemnity Act be repealed or replaced?|last=Phatey|first=Sam|date=27 April 2017|work=SMBC News|access-date=17 June 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
=== Further protests === Following the shooting, students in the country's only boarding school and several other rural towns across the Gambia launched their own protests on 11 April. Like their colleagues in Banjul, they were violently suppressed and hundreds of students were detained across the country.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
As the protests subsided, GAMSU and other human rights groups in the Gambia, including the Gambian branch of [[Amnesty International]], formed a larger group called the Coalition of Human Rights Defenders. This group was able to eventually free all those arrested on 10 and 11 April as well as increasing international awareness of the incident.<ref name=":0" />
== Legacy == It has been suggested that one of the primary motivations behind the [[2014 Gambian coup d'état attempt]] was the student massacre 14 years earlier.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://pulitzercenter.org/reporting/sixteen-years-ago-tragedy-would-ignite-coup-attempt-gambia|title=Sixteen Years Ago, a Tragedy that Would Ignite a Coup Attempt in The Gambia|last=Reid|first=Stuart A.|date=11 April 2016|work=Pulitzer Center|access-date=17 June 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
The first proper commemoration of the event took place 17 years after it happened, in April 2017. Organised by the April 10/11 Memorial Foundation a march was held followed by a symposium (http://www.april1011gambia.org/) Speaking there, [[Attorney General of the Gambia|Attorney General]] and Minister of Justice [[Ba Tambadou]] said that justice should prevail for the victims and families of those killed. He said that the [[Adama Barrow|Barrow]] government would try everything in its power to find out who gave the order to shoot the protesters and bring them to justice.<ref name=":1" />
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gambian student massacre}} [[Category:Protest-related deaths]] [[Category:Human rights in the Gambia]] [[Category:Murder in the Gambia]] [[Category:2000 in the Gambia]] [[Category:Mass murder in 2000]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/Trappist the monk|Trappist the monk]] ([[User talk:Trappist the monk|talk]]) to last version by 82.181.191.144
revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file=Polittico averoldi 01.jpg | title={{noitalic|''Averoldi Polyptych''}} | image_size = 350px | artist=Titian | year=1520–1522 | medium=oil on panel | height_metric = 278 | width_metric = 292 | museum=[[Santi Nazaro e Celso (Brescia)|Santi Nazaro e Celso]] | city = [[Brescia]] | italic title=no }} The '''''Averoldi Polyptych''''' is a painting by the Italian late Renaissance painter [[Titian]], dating to 1520–1522 and in the basilica church of [[Santi Nazaro e Celso (Brescia)|Santi Nazaro e Celso]] in [[Brescia]], northern [[Italy]].
It is signed "Ticianus Faciebat / MDXXII" on the column of the panel with St. Sebastian.
==History== The work was commissioned by Altobello Averoldi, [[papal legate]] in [[Venice]], to Titian at the time he was the official painter of the [[Republic of Venice]]. The work was delivered in 1522, as testified by Titian's signature in the lower right panel. The large polyptych was placed at the high altar of the church of Santi Nazaro e Celso of Brescia, then part of the Venetian mainland possessions, replacing another [[altarpiece]] by [[Vincenzo Foppa]] (of which now a ''Nativity of Jesus'' remains in the church of Santa Maria Assunta at [[Chiesanuova]], as well as two side panels in the [[Pinacoteca Tosio Martinengo]]).
A first version of the ''St. Sebastian'' panel was offered to [[Alfonso d'Este]] of [[Ferrara]] as a compensation for his late in the realization of the ''Bacchanalia''. The Duke declined the offer, and the early ''St. Sebastian'' was perhaps sent to [[Mantua]], where one such painting is mentioned among the artworks sold by the [[House of Gonzaga|Gonzaga]] to [[Charles I of England]], although it is no more known afterwards.<ref name=TitianCatt/>
Averoldi subsequently also started to complain about the lateness of delivery.
==Description== The use of compartment-divided polyptych, a solution rather old fashioned for the time, was surely an explicit demand of Averoldi. Titian obtained anyway a certain degree of unity, although not a spatial or architectural one as in the 15th century polyptychs: the Veneto painter adopted instead a chromatic-dynamic and light convergence towards the central scene.<ref>{{cite book|editor=Cecilia Gibellini |title=Tiziano|location=Milan|publisher=Rizzoli|year=2003}}</ref>
The panels are: *''Resurrection of Christ'', 278x122 cm *''Saints Nazarius and Celsus with Donor'', 170x65 cm *''Saint Sebastian'', 170x65 *''Angel of the Annunciation'', 79x65 cm *''Annunciation of the Virgin'', 79x65 cm
The work inspired several Brescian Renaissance painters, including [[Savoldo]] and [[Alessandro Bonvicino|Moretto]]<ref name=Zuffi>{{cite book|first=Stefano |last=Zuffi|title= Tiziano|publisher=Mondadori Arte|location=Milan |year=2008|isbn=978-88-370-6436-5}}</ref>
[[File:Polittico averoldi 02.jpg|left|thumb|upright|''The Martyrdom of [[Saint Sebastian]]'']]
===''Resurrection''=== The central scene depicts a triumphant and blazing Christ above a dawn dark yellow and grey sky, who holds the [[Crusaders|Crusader]] banner as an emblem of the Christian Catholic church. Under him is a group of soldiers with armors.
The work shows the influence of [[Raphael]]'s works such as the ''[[Transfiguration (Raphael)|Transfiguration]]'' (the centripetal position of Christ) and the fresco of the ''[[Deliverance of Saint Peter]]'' for the quasi-night atmosphere<ref name=TitianCatt>{{cite web|url=http://centropastorale.unicatt.it/centropastorale_3585.html |title=Polittico Averoldi: di fronte a tal musica si sta silenziosamente ad ascoltare - Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore |publisher=Centropastorale.unicatt.it |date= |accessdate=2014-05-01 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120721211614/http://centropastorale.unicatt.it/centropastorale_3585.html |archivedate=2012-07-21 |df= }}</ref> Another possible influence is that of [[Danube school]], in details such as the landscape illumination and the northern European fashion of the ideal Jerusalem in the background.<ref name=Zuffi/>
===''Saints Nazarius and Celsus with Donor''=== The left panel show the saints [[Nazarius and Celsus]], to which the church housing the altar was dedicated, on a gloomy background. Nazarius wear a shining armor, while his disciple, Celsus, is behind him. The kneeling donor, Altobello Averoldi, the then papal legate to Venice is portrayed from profile, and is stylistically reminiscent of the depiction of Sigismondo de' Conti in Raphael's ''[[Madonna of Foligno]]''. The influence of Titian's master, [[Giorgione]], is also visible in the calm atmosphere and the dull colors.<ref name=Zuffi/>
[[File:Tizian, Studie für den heiligen Sebastian des Hochaltars.gif|upright|thumb|Preparatory drawing for ''St. Sebastian'', now in Frankfurt's [[Städel]].]]
===''Saint Sebastian''=== The right panel shows the traditional ''Martyrdom of [[Saint Sebastian]]'', although in this case the saint is depicted in a rather contorted position which likely derived from [[Michelangelo]]'s ''Punishment of Aman'' in the [[Sistine Chapel ceiling]], or from Raphael's [[Raphael Rooms|''Fire of Borgo'']] also in the Vatican.<ref name=TitianCatt/> The arms are tied to a trunk at different heights, while the legs are also differently articulated due to the presence of a column section.
The saint's face resembles that of the Christ in the central panel, as well as that of Titian, who was thirty at the time.<ref name=TitianCatt/>
In the background is an angel, who points at Sebastian and talks with [[Saint Roch]]: prayers to both saints were invoked as a protection against the plague, and Roch's uncovered legs show the characteristic lesions.
Two preparatory drawings of the panel exist: one (16.2 x 13.6 cm) is at the [[Kupferstichkabinett Berlin|Kupferstichkabinett]] of Berlin, and another (18.3 x 11.5 cm) is in the [[Städel]] of [[Frankfurt]].
[[File:Tizian 004.jpg|thumb|upright|''[[Archangel Gabriel|Angel]] of the Annunciation'']]
===''Annunciation''=== The two upper panels show the ''[[Annunciation]]'', with the angel on the left and the Virgin on the right, according to a scheme dating to the Middle Ages. Titian painted the two figures under a powerful light, in particular the angel which is illuminated from behind.
His figure is unrolling a cartouche with the Gospel words ''Ave Gratia Plena''.
==See also== *[[List of works by Titian]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== {{commons category|Averoldi polyptych}} *{{cite book|first=Francesco |last=Valcanover|title=L'opera completa di Tiziano|publisher=Rizzoli|location=Milan|year= 1969}}
{{Titian}}
{{authority control}}
[[Category:1522 paintings]] [[Category:Annunciation in Christian art]] [[Category:Paintings by Titian]] [[Category:Polyptychs]] [[Category:Resurrection of Jesus]] [[Category:Paintings depicting Jesus]] [[Category:Paintings in Brescia]]

{{Infobox animal | name = Billy | birth_name = William Johnson Hippopotamus | othername = | species = Pygmy hippopotamus | breed = | gender = male | birth_date = Sometime in the 1920s | birth_place = Possibly [[Liberia]] | death_date = {{BirthDeathAge|||||1955|10|11}} | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | relativeage = | nationality = | occupation = | employer = | role = | years_active = | known = | tricks = | awards = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | owner = | parents = | children = 23 calves | weight = | height = | appearance = | namedafter = | website = }}
'''Billy, ''' or '''William Johnson Hippopotamus''',<ref>{{cite web |last1=Roby |first1=Marguerite |title=Goody Goody Gumdrops |url=https://siarchives.si.edu/blog/goody-goody-gumdrops |website=Smithsonian Institution Archives |accessdate=8 November 2018 |language=en |date=25 September 2012}}</ref> (1920s – October 11, 1955<ref name=Wild>{{Cite book | author = Crandall, Lee S. | title = Management of Wild Mammals in Captivity | year = 1964 | location = Chicago | publisher = [[University of Chicago Press]] }}</ref>) was a [[pygmy hippopotamus]] given to [[U.S. President]] [[Calvin Coolidge]]. Captured in Liberia, he was given to Coolidge by [[Harvey Samuel Firestone]] in 1927. Billy spent most of his life in the [[National Zoological Park (United States)|National Zoo in Washington D.C.]]. In addition to his fame as an exotic [[United States presidential pets|presidential pet]]—which afforded him a trip to the [[1939 New York World's Fair]]—Billy is also notable as the common ancestor to most pygmy hippos in American zoos.<ref name="National Zoo on pygmy hippos">{{Cite web|url=http://nationalzoo.si.edu/animals/africansavanna/factpygmyhippo.cfm |title=Pygmy Hippo fact sheet |work=nationalzoo.si.edu |publisher=[[National Zoological Park (United States)|National Zoological Park]] |accessdate=2007-11-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114022909/http://nationalzoo.si.edu/Animals/AfricanSavanna/factpygmyhippo.cfm |archivedate=2007-11-14 |df= }}</ref> By the time of his death in 1955, Billy had sired 23 calves, 13 of whom survived at least a year.
== Early years == {| class="infobox" style="float:right; clear:right; margin-left:1em; margin-right:0em; font-size:90%; width:150px;" |[[File:Harvey Samuel Firestone.jpg|150x150px]] |[[File:John Calvin Coolidge, Bain bw photo portrait.jpg|150x150px]] |- | colspan="2" width="150px"| [[Harvey Samuel Firestone]] (left) gave Billy to [[Calvin Coolidge]] (right), who donated Billy to the [[National Zoological Park (United States)|National Zoo]]. |} In 1927, [[Harvey Samuel Firestone]], the founder of the [[Firestone Tire and Rubber Company]], acquired Billy in [[Liberia]], where he was captured on one of Firestone Tires' large plantations.<ref name=NYT/> [[Calvin Coolidge]], who was the U.S. President at the time, was known for his collection of animals, including many dogs, birds, a [[wallaby]], [[lion|lion cubs]], a [[raccoon]] and other unusual animals.<ref name="WashPost on PresPets">{{cite news |url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/71665100.html?dids=71665100:71665100&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Apr+23%2C+2001&author=&pub=The+Washington+Post&edition=&startpage=C.13&desc=Pets+of+Presidents|title = Pets of Presidents, From the Dog House to the White House |work = The Washington Post |date = April 23, 2001 }}</ref> At the time, pygmy hippos were virtually unknown in the United States. On May 26, 1927, Coolidge was informed that he would receive the rare [[hippo]], already adult-sized at {{convert|6|ft|m}} long and around {{convert|600|lb|kg}}, as a gift.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Baby Hippo for Coolidge Is Coming From Liberia | work = [[The New York Times]] | date = May 27, 1927 | author = Special to The New York Times | page = 25 }}</ref>
In Coolidge's autobiography he wrote about the unusual menagerie he collected and stated that he donated many of these animals, including Billy, to the National Zoo.<ref name="Autobiography of Calvin Coolidge">[[Calvin Coolidge|Coolidge, Calvin]]. ''The Autobiography of Calvin Coolidge (1929)'', {{ISBN|1-4102-1622-5}} or {{ISBN|978-1-4102-1622-9}}</ref> Though Coolidge had a deep fascination with animals, he was overshadowed by [[Theodore Roosevelt]], who was more widely known for and associated with his interest in animals. By August 1927, Coolidge had sent the second largest collection of animals of any president after Roosevelt to the zoo, and paid them frequent visits.<ref name=NYT/> Upon his arrival, Billy was one of the most-valuable animals the zoo had ever received, and was only the eighth pygmy hippopotamus to be brought to the United States. Billy was a popular animal; several months after his arrival, ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote Billy was "as frisky as a dog. Even the antics of the monkeys go unobserved when the keeper opens the tiny hippo's cage and cuts up with him."<ref name=NYT>{{Cite news | title = Coolidge Pets Could Make Zoo of Their Own | work = [[The New York Times]] | date = August 28, 1927 }}</ref>
== Parenting troubles == Today, pygmy hippos breed well in captivity: since Billy's arrival, 58 pygmy hippos have been born at the National Zoo alone. As one of the earliest pygmy hippos in captivity in the U.S. zoo system, Billy went on to become the direct ancestor of nearly all pygmy hippos in American zoos.<ref name="National Zoo on pygmy hippos"/> When Billy first came to the zoo, however, keepers did not know much about pygmy hippopotamus [[husbandry]]. A mate for Billy, a female named Hannah, was acquired by the zoo on September 4, 1929.<ref name=WP38>{{Cite news | title = Pity the Poor Stork! He's Late With a Baby Hippo for the Zoo | author = Gross, Gerald G. | work = [[The Washington Post]] | page = X1 }}</ref> Billy's and Hannah's first calf was born on August 26, 1931, but did not survive the week. "Inability to survive the neglect of an errant mother was the cause given for baby Hippo's demise", eulogized ''[[The Washington Post]]''.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Ignored by Mother, Infant Hippo Dies | work = [[The Washington Post]] | date = August 30, 1931 | page = M3}}</ref> Over the next two years, two more calves would follow, both of which died in infancy. Billy's third calf was killed when Hannah rolled on top of the baby and crushed it. "She's just a bad mother", said the zoo's long-time director Dr. [[William M. Mann]] to ''[[The Washington Post]]'', upon the death of the third infant.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Pygmy Hippo Kills Its Third Offspring; Jungle Mother Rolls on Latest Infant and Crushes Out Life | date = May 5, 1933 | work = [[The Washington Post]] | page = 18 }}</ref>
As Hannah's fourth pregnancy progressed, zookeepers noticed she seemed to be less agitated than previous pregnancies and attributed this to their new quarters: during her previous three pregnancies, Hannah had lived in the zoo's lion house, a stressful environment for a pregnant hippo.<ref name=WP38/> On [[Mother's Day]] of 1938, Hannah gave birth to a healthy baby.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Baby-Killing Hippo Gives Birth Again at D.C. Zoo; Belated Baby Born at Zoo on Mother's Day | work = [[The Washington Post]] | date = May 9, 1938 | page = X1 }}</ref>
== Life as a stud == [[File:Musical Ride 1939 NY World Fair.jpg|thumb|Billy attended the [[1939 New York World's Fair]].]] Such was Billy's popularity in the 1930s that at the end of the decade he traveled to [[Queens]], [[New York (state)|New York]], for the [[1939 New York World's Fair]], where he appeared in the Firestone exhibit. Billy and Hannah successfully had more calves, and because of Billy's worth as a breeding stud, Mann traveled with the Smithsonian-Firestone Expedition to Liberia in 1940<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Mann |first1=William |last2=Mann |first2=Lucile Q. |authorlink1=William M. Mann |authorlink2=Lucile Quarry Mann |title=The Smithsonian-Firestone Expedition to Liberia |journal=[[The Scientific Monthly]] |date=1940 |volume=51 |issue=5 |pages=482–485 |url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/17411 |publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science}}</ref> and acquired a second mate for Billy, another female who came to be known as Matilda.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Pygmy Hippo to Become Polygamist, New Mate Captured by Expedition | work = [[The Washington Post]] | date = July 10, 1940 | page = 15 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | title = Dr. Mann Back With Rare Beasts: 300 New Tenants for Zoo Here | author = Gross, Gerald G. | work = [[The Washington Post]] | date = August 11, 1940 | page = 25}}</ref>
Between 1931 and 1954, Hannah gave birth to 15 of Billy's calves, 7 of whom were reared or lived at least one year. Between 1943 and 1956, Matilda gave birth to 8 of Billy's calves, 6 of which were reared.<ref name=Wild/> At some point during the 1940s, the press started to refer to Billy as William Johnson Hippopotamus. The zoo developed the tradition of naming all his calves Gumdrop, using [[Roman numerals]] to distinguish them. By the birth of Gumdrop XVI, the zoo had noticed something curious: of all Billy's calves, only one was male.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Baby Gumdrop Arrives at Zoo | work = [[The Washington Post]] | date = January 31, 1955 | page = 26 }}</ref> Research would later confirm that pygmy hippos in captivity are far more likely to give birth to females, though not by such an extreme ratio as Billy.<ref name=Distort>{{Cite journal | journal = [[Journal of Mammalogy]] | volume = 83 | pages = 674–681 | year = 2002 | title = Distorted Sex Ratio at Birth in the Captive Pygmy Hippopotamus, Hexaprotodon Liberiensis | author = Zschokke, Samuel | doi = 10.1644/1545-1542(2002)083<0674:DSRABI>2.0.CO;2 | issue = 3 | issn = 1545-1542}}</ref> Twenty-three years after Coolidge's death (January 5, 1933) Billy himself died on October 11, 1955,<ref name=Wild/> five months before the birth of Gumdrop XVIII. "He carried his work on to the end", said a zoo official.<ref name=WP56>{{Cite news | title = Gumdrop XVII Born At Zoo | work = [[The Washington Post]] | date = March 31, 1956 | page = 1 }}</ref> Hannah followed Billy in death on March 6, 1958.<ref name=Wild/>
== A legacy continued == After a year or two at the National Zoo, Billy's offspring were typically sent to other locations. Among the places to which his progeny were transferred: the [[Cole Bros. Circus]], [[Philadelphia Zoo|Philadelphia Zoological Gardens]], [[Catskill Game Farm]], the Miller Bros. Circus, the [[Fort Worth Zoo]], as well as international destinations such as [[Sydney]] and [[London]].<ref>{{Cite news | title = Annual Report on The National Zoological Park | publisher = [[National Zoological Park (United States)|National Zoological Park]] | location = Washington, DC | year = 1959}}</ref> In 1960, after learning that the zoo's female pygmy hippos remained without male companionship after Billy's death, [[President of Liberia|Liberian President]] [[William Tubman]] dispatched a search party to find a new male pygmy hippopotamus to ship to Washington.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Pygmy Hippopotamus Starts for Washington | work = [[Reuters]] via [[The New York Times]] | date = June 22, 1960 | page = 2 }}</ref> The pygmy hippopotamus, named Totota, arrived in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]], on February 4, 1960, and traveled via station wagon to Washington the next day, where he would continue Billy's breeding legacy with the zoo's female pygmy hippos, two of which were Billy's daughters.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Hippo Takes a Shipboard Stroll, and Misses His Washington Debut | work = [[The New York Times]] | date = February 5, 1960 | page = 29}}</ref><ref>Stroman, H.R., & Slaughter, L.M., "The care and breeding of the pygmy hippopotamus Choeropsis liberiensis in captivity", National Zoological Park, International Zoo Yearbook Vol. 12, 1972</ref>
==See also== *[[United States presidential pets]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{good article}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Billy (Pygmy Hippo)}} [[Category:1955 animal deaths]] [[Category:Individual hippopotamuses]] [[Category:United States presidential pets]] [[Category:National Zoological Park (United States)]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} [[File:Mjalexander centenarians.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Artist [[M.J. Alexander|Mary Jane Alexander]]'s portraits of centenarians at the Oklahoma Heritage Association]] A '''centenarian''' is a person who lives to (or beyond) the age of 100 years. Because [[life expectancy|life expectancies]] worldwide are below 100 years, the term is invariably associated with [[longevity]]. In 2012, the [[United Nations]] estimated that there were 316,600 living centenarians worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://www.unfpa.org/webdav/site/global/shared/documents/publications/2012/UNFPA-Report-Chapter1.pdf|title=Chapter 1: Setting the Scene|year=2012|publisher=UNFPA|format=PDF|accessdate=11 January 2013}} As life expectancy is increasing across the world, and the world population has also increased rapidly, the number of centenarians is expected to increase quickly in the future.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/1977733.stm|title=Life expectancy to soar|date=9 May 2002|work=BBC News}} According to the UK [[Office for National Statistics|ONS]], one-third of babies born in 2013 in the UK are expected to live to 100.{{cite web|url=http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/rel/lifetables/historic-and-projected-data-from-the-period-and-cohort-life-tables/2012-based/sty-babies-living-to-100.html|title=[ARCHIVED CONTENT] One third of babies born in 2013 are expected to live to 100|date=11 December 2013|publisher=ONS|accessdate=1 May 2016}} ==Supercentenarian== A [[supercentenarian]], sometimes hyphenated as '''super-centenarian''', is a human (or individual species) who has lived to the age of 110 or more, something only achieved by about one in 1,000 centenarians. Even rarer is a person [[List of the verified oldest people|who has lived to age 115]] – there are only 46 people in [[recorded history]] who have indisputably reached this age, of whom only Kane Tanaka, Maria Giuseppa Robucci and Shimoe Akiyama are living as of 2018.{{cite web |url=http://www.soa.org/library/journals/north-american-actuarial-journal/2002/july/naaj0207_6.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100703065315/http://www.soa.org/library/journals/north-american-actuarial-journal/2002/july/naaj0207_6.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=3 July 2010 |title=Emergence of supercentenarians in low-mortality countries |work=North American Actuarial Journal (Vol. 6) |year=2002 |format=PDF |accessdate=4 November 2010 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.supercentenarians.org/publications.htm |title=Publications |doi=10.1016/S0531-5565 |publisher=Supercentenarians.org |accessdate=4 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613010740/http://www.supercentenarians.org/publications.htm |archivedate=13 June 2010 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/978-3-642-11519-6 |title=Supercentenarians by H. Maier, J. Gampe, B. Jeune, J.-M. Robine and J.W. Vaupel. Springer 2010 |publisher=Springerlink.com |accessdate=4 November 2010}} There has only been one known case of a person of 120 years of age or older whose birth was independently verified by historical documents: [[Jeanne Calment]], who lived to the age of 122 years, 164 days. ==Current incidences== [[Japan]] currently has the greatest number of known centenarians of any nation with 67,824 according to their 2017 census, along with the highest proportion of centenarians at 34.85 per 100,000 people. Japan started recording its centenarians in 1963. The number of Japanese centenarians in that year was 153, but surpassed the 10,000 mark in 1998; 20,000 in 2003; and 40,000 in 2009. According to a 1998 [[United Nations]] demographic survey, Japan is expected to have 272,000 centenarians by 2050;{{cite web |url= https://www.un.org/NewLinks/older/99/older.htm |title= Demographics of older persons |publisher=UN |date=1 October 1998 |accessdate=4 November 2010}} other sources suggest that the number could be closer to 1 million.{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7612363.stm |title= Japan centenarians at record high |publisher= BBC News |date= 12 September 2008 |accessdate=4 November 2010}} The incidence of centenarians in Japan was one per 3,522 people in 2008.[http://www.avmaroc.com/pdf/centenaires-japon-actualite-a140600-d.pdf ''De plus en plus de centenaires au Japon'' (PDF)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927131702/http://www.avmaroc.com/pdf/centenaires-japon-actualite-a140600-d.pdf |date=27 September 2011 }}. Agence France Presse via Avmaroc.com. 12 September 2008. Retrieved 24 February 2013. In Japan, the number of centenarians is highly skewed towards females. Japan in fiscal year 2016 had 57,525 female centenarians, while males were 8,167, a ratio of 7:1. The increase of centenarians was even more skewed at 11.6:1.{{cite news|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2016/09/13/national/aging-japan-now-65692-centenarians/ |title= Aging Japan now has 65692 centenarians |date= 2013-09-13 |access-date= 2017-04-22 |work= The Japan Times}} ==Centenarian populations by country== The total number of living centenarians in the world remains uncertain. It was estimated by the [https://www.un.org/en/development/desa/population/ Population Division] of the United Nations as 23,000 in 1950, 110,000 in 1990, 150,000 in 1995, 209,000 in 2000, 324,000 in 2005[http://esa.un.org/unpp "World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision"] {{webarchive |url= https://web.archive.org/web/20071216015218/http://esa.un.org/unpp/ |date=16 December 2007 }}. United Nations. Retrieved 24 February 2013. and 455,000 in 2009.[https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/WPA2009/WPA2009-report.pdf "World Population Ageing 2009"]. (PDF) ST/ESA/SER.A/295. Population Division – Department of Economic and Social Affairs. United Nations. October 2010. p.27. However, these older estimates did not take into account the contemporary downward adjustments of national estimates made by several countries such as the United States; thus, in 2012, the UN estimated there to be only 316,600 centenarians worldwide. The following table gives estimated centenarian populations by country, including both the latest and the earliest known estimates, where available. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Country !! data-sort-type="number" |Latest estimate (year) !! data-sort-type="number" | Earliest estimate (year) !! data-sort-type="number" | Centenarians per
100,000 people |- |'''[[Andorra]]'''|| 7 (2002){{cite web |url=http://medlem.spray.se/celvin/infostat_AD.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040530183757/http://medlem.spray.se/celvin/infostat_AD.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=30 May 2004 |title=Andorra |year=2002 |publisher=Medlem.spray.se |quote=Note: Overreported figures, the actual number is around 7 centenarians. The registration of deaths in the period 1948-1994 is considered less than 90% complete, see [http://157.62.21.4/SHARE1/UN%20Demographics/html/table10//10502805.htm this table], thus a number of deceased are still included in the population statistics. |accessdate=22 April 2013 }} || – || 10.2 |- |'''[[Argentina]]'''|| 3,487 (2010)[http://www.censo2010.indec.gov.ar/cuadrosDefinitivos/Total_pais/P5-P_Total_pais.xls Indec 2010 Cuadro – Total del país. Población total por país de nacimiento, según sexo y grupo de edad (in Spanish)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111016011614/http://censo2010.indec.gov.ar/cuadrosDefinitivos/Total_pais/P5-P_Total_pais.xls |date=16 October 2011 }}. 2010.
